docs.lead_paragraph: The tactics and concessions used to produce a health care bill have turned off some Colorado residents who stand to benefit from it.

docs.lead_paragraph: A government report finds that from 2000 to 2008, makers or distributors raised the prices of 416 brand-name drug products at least once by 100 percent or more.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'm a middle-of-the-road kind of guy. I want the Democrats out of my pocket and Republicans out of my bedroom. The one word I would use for what's going on in Washington is embarrassing. Ron Vaughn, who provides health insurance to his 60 employees at Argonaut Wine and Liquor in Denver. [A10]
docs.snippet: I'm a middle-of-the-road kind of guy. I want the Democrats out of my pocket and Republicans out of my bedroom. The one word I would use for what's going on in Washington is embarrassing.     Ron Vaughn, who provides health insurance to his 60...

docs.lead_paragraph: As White House and Congressional negotiators work toward an agreement on a final version of sweeping health care legislation, they seem likely to push the 10-year price tag closer to the $1.05 trillion cost of the House-passed bill while relying on new taxes proposed by the Senate, probably including a bigger increase in the Medicare payroll tax than currently proposed. As small teams of Congressional staff members work furiously to hash out the final differences between the two versions, Congressional leaders and White House officials are trying to navigate an increasingly difficult set of competing demands while also fulfilling President Obama's top goals: that the legislation not add to the deficit, that it reduce long-term health spending and that it cost around $900 billion.

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Congressional leaders and White House officials try to navigate competing demands while working toward agreement on final version of health care legislation; they are likely to push 10-year price tag closer to $1.05 trillion cost of House-passed bill while relying on new taxes proposed by Senate; House demands include subsidies to help lower-income people buy private health insurance; Senate is pressing federal government to pay for Medicaid expansion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama said that Americans would see immediate benefits from health care reform when it is enacted.

headline.main: Obama Urges Quick Action on Health Overhaul
headline.print_headline: Obama Urges Quick Action On Overhaul

docs.snippet: President Obama said that Americans would see immediate benefits from health care reform when it is enacted.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his weekly address, the president urged Congress to swiftly reconcile differences over the legislation so it could be signed into law in the coming weeks.

headline.main: Obama Says Benefits From Health Care Overhaul Would Be Immediate
